security: The document reveals discussions about intelligence gathering and analysis related to Cuba during the Cuban Missile Crisis. Specifically, it mentions the limited distribution of intelligence information to the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB), the CIA's covert operations, and the challenges in obtaining reliable intelligence from within Cuba. Sharing details about intelligence limitations and covert activities could compromise ongoing intelligence operations and diplomatic strategies. Quoting directly: 'a top level decision was made to give limited distribution of intelligence information on Cuba and the Board was excluded from those elements of the government which were designated to receive it.'
summary: Minutes from a November 9, 1962, meeting of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB) discuss intelligence related to Cuba, including Soviet missile buildup, covert operations, and challenges in gathering information from within Cuba.
summary_one_paragraph: The PFIAB convened on November 9, 1962, to discuss intelligence matters, primarily focusing on the Soviet missile buildup in Cuba. Topics included preliminary reviews of recent Cuban developments, discussions with the Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) and the State Department, and updates on CIA covert operations. The board addressed concerns about limited intelligence distribution, difficulties in obtaining reliable information from within Cuba, and the transfer of reconnaissance responsibilities from the CIA to SAC. The meeting also covered the review of Soviet nuclear tests and U.S. intelligence activities in various countries.
title: PRESIDENT'S FOREIGN INTELLIGENCE ADVISORY BOARD MEETING OF THE BOARD NOVEMBER 9, 1962
